Class JPPluginAPI

java.lang.Object
com.tom.jpedit.plugins.JPPluginAPI
public class JPPluginAPI extends Object
This class helps plugins interface with JPEdit. Rather than having unfettered access to all internal APIs this class provides a guaranteed way to interact with the application that will not cause conflicts or issues.

For example, there are methods in ApplicationContext that should not be called by plugins but, the entire ApplicationContext class is exposed due to constraints in visibility.

The true remedy for this is Java Modules which will completely limit access to ApplicationContext. However, this class will serve as an intermediary, ironing out the proper public UI while leaving ApplicationContext exposed so as to not break any existing plugins. However in the future Modules will be used and all access will have to be through designated APIs like this class as other classes will be inaccessible

  • Method Details

    • getFileContentForPlugin

      @NotNull public static @NotNull String getFileContentForPlugin(Class<? extends JPEditPlugin> pluginClass, @NotNull @NotNull Path path, Charset charset) throws IOException
      Convenience method that uses getFileForPlugin(Class, Path) to obtain a file and then reads the entire contents of the file into a string and returns that string to the caller
      Parameters:
      pluginClass - your class that implements JPEditPlugin
      path - the path you would like to write to
      charset - charset for file contents. if not needed use Charset.defaultCharset()
      Returns:
      the contents of the file as a string
      Throws:
      IOException - if the file does not exist or cannot be read or written

    • getFileForPlugin

      @NotNull public static @NotNull File getFileForPlugin(Class<? extends JPEditPlugin> pluginClass, @NotNull @NotNull Path path) throws IOException
      Requests a file from the Application for use by the plugin. The file returned is read/writeable or else an IOException is thrown. The path provided cannot be absolute, to a directory, or inaccessible or an IOException is thrown.

      If this method returns successfully with a File object, then that file is guaranteed to exist and be read/writeable

      Parameters:
      pluginClass - your class that implements JPEditPlugin
      path - the path you would like to write to
      Returns:
      a File object which represents the file which your plugin has rights to use for whatever purpose it deems fit
      Throws:
      IOException - if the parameter is an absolute path or not read/writeable

    • setLocalUserPreference

      public static void setLocalUserPreference(@NotNull @NotNull Class<? extends JPEditPlugin> mainClass, String property, String value)
      Convenience method to set preferences for this plugin only to ensure that the plugin is not trampling built-in preferences or the preferences of other plugins. Uses pluginQualifiedName(Class) to avoid collisions
      Parameters:
      mainClass - the main plugin class implementing JPEditPlugin
      property - the name of the preference to save
      value - the value of the saved preference

    • getUserPreferences

      public static UserPreferences getUserPreferences()
      Get the users saved preferences Object. See UserPreferences.

      Generally this method can be used for getting and modifying Application default settings-namely ones that already exist in the program. If you want to set new settings specific to your plugin, it is better to call setLocalUserPreference(Class, String, String) since this method sets a preference with the plugin package name prepended to the key to avoid trampling other plugins' or future built-in preference keys

      Returns:
      User's preferences

      value - the value of the property

    • showConfirmation

      public static ConfirmationType showConfirmation(String title, String prompt, String message)
      Show the user a Yes/No/Cancel dialog. The dialog is modal and execution of the program will block until the dialog is closed. The response of the user is returned.

      Messages should be phrased as a yes or no question consistent with the phrasing of other yes/no/cancel prompts throughout the program.

      Generally, a ConfirmationType of Yes indicates perform the prompted action and continue. A Type of No indicates the prompted action should *not* take place but the program should continue. A type of Cancel indicates that the action should not be taken *and* the program should *not* continue and rather maintain the exact same state as it did *before* displaying the prompt

      Parameters:
      title - Window title
      prompt - Main text
      message - Detailed message
      Returns:
      ConfirmationType representing the User's choice.

    • showAlert

      public static void showAlert(String title, String prompt, String message)
      Show a modal alter with an OK button. Thread is blocked until alert is closed
      Parameters:
      title - Window title
      prompt - Main text
      message - Detailed message

    • showAlertNonModal

      public static void showAlertNonModal(String title, String prompt, String message)
      Show an alert with an OK button. Thread is not blocked. Program continues executing after the prompt is shown even before the user responds
      Parameters:
      title - Window title
      prompt - Main text
      message - Detailed message
